elements.content: A series of complexes constructed from multinuclear copper clusters and polyoxometalates, namely, [Cu6(PO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)6](H3O)2[P2W18O62](bpy=2,2′-bipyridine, 1), [Cu6(PO4)2(H2O)4(phen)6](H2O)2[P2W18O62] (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, 2), [Cu2Cl(phen)4][PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)4(phen)4](H3O)2[PV3W9O40] (4), and [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)4](H2O)2[PVW11O40] (5), have been successfully synthesized in situ under hydrothermal conditions via changing the ligand, adjusting the pH value, and introducing low-valence metal (V5+). Complex 1 represents the first example of 1D linear chain constructed from alternating mixed-valence hexacopper (four Cu2+ and two Cu+) clusters and Wells−Dawson type polyoxometalates. Complex 2 exhibits an unprecedented 2D layer network based on hexacopper phosphate and Wells−Dawson type polyoxometalates. Complex 3 constructed from dicopper coordination compounds and Keggin polyoxometalates, was obtained from the similar hydrothermal treatment of 2 at much lower pH value. Complexes 4−5 represent the first two examples of 1D linear chain constructed from alternating tetracopper phosphate cations and V5+-substituted Keggin type polyoxometalates. The magnetic properties of the complexes have been investigated between 2 and 300 K.

The magnetic properties of the complexes have been investigated between 2 and 300 K.

Complexes 1−5 were synthesized in situ under hydrothermal reaction conditions via changing the ligand, adjusting the pH value, and introducing low-valence metal ion (V5+).

Introduction

Polyoxometalates (POMs), which are nanosized metal-oxide clusters and unusually effective inorganic ligands, have been widely investigated because of their distinctive topological structures and versatile applications in given fields, especially in catalysis, medicine, biology, electrochromism, magnetizm, and material science. One promising approach for the design of organic−inorganic hybrid materials is to build connections between the surface oxygen atoms of POMs and metal coordination compounds. Such kinds of connections can be direct interaction, weak interaction, hydrogen bonding, π−π stacking, etc. As is well-known, suitable combination of metal/ligand/POM is a main factor of design and construction of POM-based hybrids. Copper(II), as secondary transition metal, is frequently selected by preference for assembly of the polynuclear metal clusters and has a key role in the formation of the hybrid materials because of its capacity to adopt various coordination number and the Jahn−Teller effect allowing an elongation of the axial Cu−O distances. To date, many organic−inorganic hybrids based on copper coordination compounds and POM building blocks have been synthesized and studied. Moreover, ligands also play a key role in the formation of complexes owing to their different steric effect, soft-rigid degree and structure. Recently, we have reported a novel 1D chain compound, [Cu6(PO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)6](H3O)2[P2W18O62](bpy=2,2′-bipyridine, 1), constructed from alternating mixed-valence hexacopper (four Cu2+ and two Cu+) phosphate cations with bpy ligand and Wells−Dawson polyoxoanions. The successful preparation of complex 1 inspired us to use other ligand, such as 4,4′-bipyridine or phen, to study the effect on the construction of Cu/ligand/POM hybrids. Otherwise, during the preparation, two strategies have been exploited to improve the surface charge density and activate the surface oxygen atoms of POMs in order to increase coordination ability of POM building blocks: (1) reduce the metal centers from a high oxidation state to a low oxidation state; (2) replace high-valence metal centers with lower-valence ones, for instance, from W6+ to V5+ or 4+ or TM (TM = transition metal). For example, the 1D complex, [Cu5(HPO4)(PO4)(H2O)(bpy)5][PW11CuO39]·6H2O, based on Cu2+-substituted Keggin anion and multicopper phosphate cluster, and [Ag(bpy)]2[Ag2(bpy)3]2[PW9V3O40] constructed from V5+−substituted Keggin POMs, were synthesized. Peng’s group has also isolated a series of V4+-capped polyoxometalates by combining such two methods.

elements.content: On the other hand, although the hydrothermal technique has been extensively used to prepare organic−inorganic hybrid materials, some factors influencing the outcome of reaction are still ambiguous, such as pH value, initial reactant, starting concentration, and reaction temperature. Many research studies have made efforts in order to understand fully the effects of these factors. Peng’s group reported two high-dimensional and high-connected silver complexes of POMs by using the presynthesized Wells−Dawson POM building blocks at different pH value. Long’s group have also studied the influences of the pH values on the structures of complexes based on presynthesized Keggin POMs. However, the research that how to control the initial pH value of the system to synthesize in situ organic−inorganic hybrids based on different type POM building blocks and multinuclear copper coordination compounds with bpy or phen ligands, has been not reported yet.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without purification. The hydrothermal reactions were carried out in 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves under autogenously pressure with a fill factor of approximately 70%. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Cu, W, V, and P were determined by a Jobin Yvon Ultima2 ICP atomic emission Spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in the range 400−4000 cm−1 on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis was recorded with a NETZSCH STA449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was performed with a Rigaku DMAX 2500 diffractometer. Magnetic susceptibility data were measured on a finely ground crystalline sample of complexes 2−5 using a model PPMS60000 magnetometer in the temperature range 2−300 K with an applied field of 2000 G.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without purification. The hydrothermal reactions were carried out in 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves under autogenously pressure with a fill factor of approximately 70%. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried on an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Cu, W, V, and P were determined by a Jobin Yvon Ultima2 ICP atomic emission Spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis was recorded with a NETZSCH STA449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was performed with a Rigaku DMAX 2500 diffractometer. Magnetic susceptibility data were measured on a finely ground crystalline sample of complexes 2-5 using a model PPMS60000 magnetometer in the temperature range 2-300 K with an applied field of 2000 G.

elements.content: A mixture of Na2WO4·2H2O (0.383 g, 1.16 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.032 g, 0.19 mmol), H3PO4 (0.5 mL, 85%), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.023 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (18 mL) was stirred for 30 min, and the pH was adjusted to 2.5−3 with 2 M NaOH solution. The resulting suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (25 mL) and kept at 160 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature for 2 days, blue prism crystals of 1 were obtained by filtering and were washed with distilled water and dried in desiccators at ambient temperature. The yield was ca. 42% based on W. Elemental anal. Calcd (%) for C72H60Cu6N12O76P4W18 (2) (M r = 6123.74) (%): W, 54.04; Cu, 6.23; P, 2.02; C, 14.12; H, 0.99; N, 2.75. Found (%): W, 53.69; Cu, 6.19; P, 2.27; C, 14.32; H, 1.06; N, 2.83.

elements.content: Structural measurements for complexes 1−5 was performed on a Mercury 70 (2 × 2 bin mode) diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 20 °C. Empirical from equivalents were made from ψ-scan data using the program SHELXTL 97 at the data reduction stage along with the correction for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structure analysis was performed by using the Crystal Structure crystallographic program package. The structure of complexes 1−5 was solved by the direct methods (Wingx32, SIR-92), and successive Fourier difference syntheses. The final structure was examined with the program PLATON and no additional symmetry element was detected. All the heavy atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html. Crystal parameters and other experimental details of the data collection for complexes 1−5 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S1−Table S4 of the .

X-ray Crystallography

Structural measurements for complexes 1-5 was performed on a Mercury 70 (2 × 2 bin mode) diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 20 °C. Empirical from equivalents were made from ψ-scan data using the program SHELXTL 97 at the data reduction stage along with the correction for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structure analysis was performed by using the Crystal Structure crystallographic program package. The structure of complexes 1-5 was solved by the direct methods (Wingx32, SIR-92), and successive Fourier difference syntheses. The final structure was examined with the program PLATON and no additional symmetry element was detected. All the heavy atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html. elements.content:
CCDC reference numbers 680366, 721722, 721879, 685603, and 695498 for complexes 1−5, respectively.

Results and DiscussionSyntheses

All the complexes were synthesized in situ under hydrothermal reaction conditions. During the research, we found that ligand, pH value and low-valence metal can influence the final products. The self-assembly reaction of Na2WO4·2H2O, CuCl2·2H2O, H3PO4, bpy, and H2O gave rise to complex 1 with an unprecedented 1D linear chain based on mixed-valence hexacopper (four Cu2+ and two Cu+) phosphate cations and Wells−Dawson polyoxoanions. This enlightened us to change the ligand to construct high dimensional network under similar condition. Unfortunately, when 4,4′-bipyridine was used, no suitable crystal was obtained; however, when phen was introduced into the reaction, complex 2 constructed from hexacopper phosphate cations and Wells−Dawson type polyoxoanions was successfully isolated. At much lower pH value under the similar hydrothermal treatment of 2, complex 3 constructed from dicopper coordination compounds and Keggin polyoxometalates was also isolated. To investigate the influence of lower-valence metal on the products, NH4VO3 containing V5+ was introduced into this system. It is very interesting that we successfully obtained complexes 4−5 exhibiting similar 1D linear chain constructed from tetracopper phosphate cations and V5+-substituted Keggin POM anions, which are distinctly different from complex 3. The formations of 1−5 are shown in Scheme .

Results and Discussion

Syntheses

All the complexes were synthesized in situ under hydrothermal reaction conditions. During the research, we found that ligand, pH value and low-valence metal can influence the final products. The self-assembly reaction of Na2WO4⋅2H2O, CuCl2⋅2H2O, H3PO4, bpy, and H2O gave rise to complex 1 with an unprecedented 1D linear chain based on mixed-valence hexacopper (four Cu2+ and two Cu+) phosphate cations and Wells-Dawson polyoxoanions. This enlightened us to change the ligand to construct high dimensional network under similar condition. Unfortunately, when 4,4'-bipyridine was used, no suitable crystal was obtained; however, when phen was introduced into the reaction, complex 2 constructed from hexacopper phosphate cations and Wells-Dawson type polyoxoanions was successfully isolated. At much lower pH value under the similar hydrothermal treatment of 2, complex 3 constructed from dicopper coordination compounds and Keggin polyoxometalates was also isolated. To investigate the influence of lower-valence metal on the products, NH4VO3 containing V5+ was introduced into this system. It is very interesting that we successfully obtained complexes 4-5 exhibiting similar 1D linear chain constructed from tetracopper phosphate cations and V5+-substituted Keggin POM anions, which are distinctly different from complex 3. The formations of 1-5 are shown in Scheme .

Crystal Structure of 1 

Complex 1, [Cu6(PO4)2(H2O)2(2,2'-bpy)6](H3O)2[P2W18O62], constructed from alternating mixed-valence hexacopper (four Cu2+ and two Cu+) phosphate cations with bpy ligand and Wells-Dawson POM building blocks, is 1D linear chain exhibiting an -ACACAC- type structure. The structure was reported previously and will not be discussed here (Figures S1 and S2 in the ).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that complex 2 consists of one [P2W18O62]6− polyoxoanion, six Cu2+ cations, two PO4 3− anions, four phen ligands, and six water molecules (Figure a). The [P2W18O62]6− polyoxoanion exhibits Wells−Dawson structure and contains two PW9 halves linked by almost linear W−Ob−W bonds. The Wells−Dawson type polyoxoanion, which acts as tridentate inorganic ligand to coordinate three copper ions (Figure b), is very similar to that in complex 1. The W−O and P−O bond lengths are in the normal ranges (see Table S1 in the ). Bond valence sum calculations show that all tungsten atoms are in +VI oxidation states, and copper atoms are in +II oxidation states.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2 

Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that complex 2 consists of one [P2W18O62]6- polyoxoanion, six Cu2+ cations, two PO4 3- anions, four phen ligands, and six water molecules (Figure a). The [P2W18O62]6- polyoxoanion exhibits Wells-Dawson structure and contains two PW9 halves linked by almost linear W-Ob-W bonds. The Wells-Dawson type polyoxoanion, which acts as tridentate inorganic ligand to coordinate three copper ions (Figure b), is very similar to that in complex 1. The W-O and P-O bond lengths are in the normal ranges (see Table S1 in the ). Bond valence sum calculations show that all tungsten atoms are in +VI oxidation states, and copper atoms are in +II oxidation states.

elements.content: The most striking structural feature of complex 2 is the presence of two similar hexacopper phosphate cluster [Cu6(PO4)2(H2O)4(phen)6]6+ (Figure ). Each cluster contains two PO4 tetrahedron, six copper atoms, six phen ligands, and four coordinated water molecules. All four oxygen atoms of each PO4 3− participate in coordination, two of them function as μ2-bridge linking two copper atoms, and each of the other two coordinates to one copper atom. As shown in structures c and d in Figure , six copper atoms are linked by two tetrahedral PO4 to form a unique hexacopper octahedron cluster. In the first hexacopper octahedron cluster, the equatorial plane is occupied by Cu(1), Cu(3), Cu(1′), and Cu(3′) atoms, whereas Cu(2) and Cu(2′) lie at the apexes. It is very interesting that the three copper ions have different coordination environments. The Cu(1) ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of phen ligand (Cu(1)−N(3) = 1.994(9) and Cu(1)−N(4) = 2.054(4) Å), two oxygen atoms of different phosphate groups (Cu(1)−O(63′) = 2.023(8) and Cu(1)−O(66′) = 1.938) Å), and one terminal oxygen atom O(1) located at the “cap” site of the [P2W18O62]6− cluster to form a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The sixth potentially bonding position is occupied by O(64′) from the PO4 anions with Cu(1)−O(64′) being 2.936(11) Å) and may be considered as a weak semicoordination (Figure a). The structure is very rare, and can be regarded as 4 + 1 + 1′ six-coordinate code. The six-coordinated Cu(2) ion displays an elongated octahedral CuO4N2 coordination geometry for the Jahn−Teller effect, defined by two nitrogen atoms from phen ligand (Cu(2)−N(1) = 2.032(12), Cu(2)−N(2)= 2.019(12) Å), one oxygen atoms from phosphate groups (Cu(2)−O(65) = 1.949(10) Å), two water ligands (Cu(2)−O(2w) = 2.267(11) Å, Cu(2)−O(3w) = 2.019(11) Å), and one terminal oxygen atom (Cu(2)−O(2) = 2.588(10) Å) located at the “belt” site of the [P2W18O62]6− Wells−Dawson cluster, which exhibits 4 + 2 coordination mode. The surrounding of Cu(3) ion is 4 + 1 coordination mode in a distorted square-based pyramidal geometry, formed by two nitrogen atoms from phen ligand (Cu(3)−N(5) = 1.995(9), Cu(3)−N(6) = 2.010(9) Å), and three oxygen atoms from two different phosphate groups(Cu(3)−O(63) = 1.964(8), Cu(3)−O(64) = 1.917(7), and Cu(3)−O(66) = 2.724(8) Å). In the second hexacopper phosphate cluster (Figure b), the Cu(4), Cu(5), and Cu(6) atoms have same coordination mode and each of them is five-coordinated in square pyramid geometry. Cu(4) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of phen ligand (Cu(4)−N(8) = 2.024 (9) and Cu(4)−N(9)=2.038(9) Å), two oxygen atoms from different phosphate groups (Cu(4)−O(67) = 1.946(8) and Cu(4)−O(68) = 2.005(8)Å), and one terminal oxygen atom O(3) (Cu(4)−O(3) = 2.189(8) Å) from the [P2W18O62]6− Wells−Dawson cluster to form a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Cu(5) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from phen ligand, one oxygen atom from the phosphate group, and two coordination water molecules. Cu(6) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of phen ligand, and three oxygen atoms from two different phosphate groups. It should be noted that in the second hexacopper cluster only two copper atoms connect the Wells−Dawson anions through Cu−O interaction, whereas in the first hexacopper cluster, four copper atoms directly coordinate to POMs (structures c and d in Figure ). This influences the connection mode in the construction of 3D network. The two different hexacopper phosphate clusters and the [P2W18O62]6− anions alternately connect each other through the terminal oxygen atom (O(1), O(2), and O(3)) located at the “cap” or “belt” site of the Wells−Dawson type anion to form 2D plane. The structure exhibits (6,4)-topological network (Figure a) and is different from that of complex 1. To the best of our knowledge, complex 2 represents the first example of a 2D framework containing Wells-Dawson type POM building blocks linked by two different hexacopper phosphate cations.

elements.content: Complexes 1−2 have different structural dimensions. It is very interesting that changing the ligand from bpy to phen has resulted in a different assembling process. It may be noted that the first hexacopper phosphate clusters of complex 2 is very different from the hexacopper cluster in complex 1. First, each apex copper atom (Cu(2), Cu(2′)) of the former has two coordinated waters, while the latter has one coordinated water. Second, the bpy ligands coordinated to apex coppers (Cu(1), Cu(1′)) in complex 1 are disordered and adopt a slightly twisted conformation (see Figure S3 in the ); and for phen, such a deformation is impossible. The similar phenomena are also observed in complexes 4−5 (see below). Moreover, the former has four copper atoms coordinating to Wells−Dawson type POMs (Figure c), whereas the latter only has two copper atoms coordinating to POMs (see Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). This different connection mode strongly influences the structural dimensions of complexes 1−2.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the noncoordinate lattice water molecules of complex 2, which lie in the gap of the polyoxoanions and hexacopper phosphate cations, have interaction with adjacent atoms via hydrogen-bonding. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S5 of the , their peripheral hydrogen bonding sites are presented in Figure . The two dimer supramolecular clusters consist of O(1w) and O(4w), O(6w) and O(2w) water molecules (O(1w)···O(4w) 2.75 Å, O(6w)···O(2w) 2.87 Å), respectively. For comparison, the corresponding values in regular ice, liquid water, and vapor phase of the dimer water are 2.74, 2.85, and 2.98 Å, respectively. Small water clusters are a subject of both theoretical and experimental research because they can provide insight into the structure and characteristics of bulk water, bulk ice and liquid water. Here, the two dimer supramolecular clusters have interaction with its peripheral oxygen atoms (O(4), O(7), O(5), and O(6)) of 2 via hydrogen-bonding. The two dimer water clusters act as a “glue” to assemble the 2D layer containing Wells−Dawson type polyoxoanions and two different hexacopper phosphate cations, forming a 3D network via hydrogen bonding along the bc plane (Figure b).

elements.content: Complex 3 was isolated from the similar hydrothermal treatment of 2 at a much lower pH value. The X-ray structure analysis reveals that complex 3 consists of centrosymmetric related copper(II) binuclear units [Cu2Cl(phen)4]3+, and traditional Keggion type polyoxoanion [PW12O40]3− (Figure a). In complex 3, two copper atoms, bridged by one chlorine to form a binuclear synthon with Cu−Cu distance of 4.439 Å, do not coordinate to the saturated Keggin type polyoxoanions. The distorted square-grid coordination environment of copper atom is completed by four nitrogen atoms of two phen ligands (Cu−N = 1.977(11)−2.112(10) Å, see Table S2 in the ), and one chlorine anion (Cu(1)−Cl(1) = 2.112(10)Å). The C−H···O hydrogen bonds (C−O = 3.155 Å, see Table S6 in the ), between phen ligands and oxygen atoms of the POMs (Figure b), have a key role during the construction of 3D the supramolecular architecture of complex 3.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 3 

Complex 3 was isolated from the similar hydrothermal treatment of 2 at a much lower pH value. The X-ray structure analysis reveals that complex 3 consists of centrosymmetric related copper(II) binuclear units [Cu2Cl(phen)4]3+, and traditional Keggion type polyoxoanion [PW12O40]3- (Figure a). In complex 3, two copper atoms, bridged by one chlorine to form a binuclear synthon with Cu-Cu distance of 4.439 Å, do not coordinate to the saturated Keggin type polyoxoanions. The distorted square-grid coordination environment of copper atom is completed by four nitrogen atoms of two phen ligands (Cu-N = 1.977(11)-2.112(10) Å, see Table S2 in the ), and one chlorine anion (Cu(1)-Cl(1) = 2.112(10)Å). The C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (C-O = 3.155 Å, see Table S6 in the ), between phen ligands and oxygen atoms of the POMs (Figure b), have a key role during the construction of 3D the supramolecular architecture of complex 3.

elements.content: Complexes 4−5 were successfully obtained by introducing the low valence heteroatom (V5+) in order to improve the surface charge density of POMs and the coordination ability of POMs. Complex 4 consists of a Keggin type anion [PV3W9O40]6−, a tetracopper phosphate cation [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)4(phen)4]4+, and two noncoordinated water molecules, as shown in Figure . The location of the W6+ and V5+ metallic centers is interesting. From electron density maps, it is clear that W6+ and V5+ are statistically disordered (fixed rate of occupancy 0.75 W, 0.25 V), which was also confirmed by element analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 4-5 

Complexes 4-5 were successfully obtained by introducing the low valence heteroatom (V5+) in order to improve the surface charge density of POMs and the coordination ability of POMs. Complex 4 consists of a Keggin type anion [PV3W9O40]6-, a tetracopper phosphate cation [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)4(phen)4]4+, and two noncoordinated water molecules, as shown in Figure . The location of the W6+ and V5+ metallic centers is interesting. From electron density maps, it is clear that W6+ and V5+ are statistically disordered (fixed rate of occupancy 0.75 W, 0.25 V), which was also confirmed by element analysis.

elements.content: The structure of tetracopper phosphate cluster [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)4(phen)4]4+ (Figure a) is different from that reported in literature. The cluster contains two PO4 tetrahedral, four Cu atoms, four phen ligands, and four coordinated water molecules. Three oxygen atoms of each PO4 3− participate in coordination, one of them functions as μ2-bridge linking two Cu atoms, and each of the other two coordinates to one Cu atom. And the fourth oxygen atom O(23) is protonated, which is confirmed by valence bond calculations (bond valence sum for O(23) is 1.21). Thus, four copper atoms are linked by two PO4 tetrahedron to form a unique tetracopper parallelogram array. It is very interesting that Cu(1) and Cu(2) have different coordination environment. The six-coordinated Cu(1) ion displays an elongated octahedral CuO4N2 coordination geometry, formed by two nitrogen atoms from phen ligand (Cu(1)−N(1) = 1.979(12), Cu(1)−N(2) = 2.024(12) Å), two oxygen atoms from different phosphate groups (Cu(1)−O(25) = 2.453(10), Cu(1)−O(26) = 1.959(10) Å), one water ligand (Cu(1)−O(1w) = 1.962(11) Å), and one terminal oxygen (Cu(1)−O(13)= 2.788(10) Å) of Keggin anions. Although the corresponding Cu(1)−O(13) distance is slightly long, as a result of the Jahn−Teller effect, we consider that this bond does exist. While the surrounding of Cu(2) ion is 4 + 1 coordination mode in a distorted square-based pyramidal geometry, formed by two nitrogen atoms from phen ligand (Cu(2)−N(3) = 2.058(13), Cu(2)−N(4) = 1.993(13) Å), two oxygen atoms from two different phosphate groups (Cu(2)−O(24) = 1.932(11), Cu(2)−O(25) = 1.970(10) Å), and one terminal water ligand (Cu(2)−O(2w)= 2.255 (13) Å) (see Table S3 in the ). Thus, the tetracopper phosphate cations and the V5+-substituted Keggin anions alternately connect each other through the terminal oxygen atom O(13) to form 1D linear chain exhibiting −ACACAC− type structure (Figure ).

elements.content: It is interesting to note that the two noncoordinate water molecules are protonated for the requirement of charge balance, and interact with their immediate atoms by hydrogen-bonding (see Figure S4a and Table S7 in the ). Along the ac plane, the one-dimensional linear chains are connected via the hydrogen-bonding to give two-dimensional framework (Figure a). As seen from Figure b, the phen ligands form two-dimensional plane through π−π stacking along the bc plane. Thus, complex 4 forms a 3D supramolecular framework through hydrogen-bonding, Cu−O interaction, and π−π stacking.

elements.content: Complex 5, which was synthesized from the similar treatment of 4 except for phen replaced by bpy, also consists of a Keggin type anion [PVW11O40]4− (W and V are crystallographically disordered, fixed rate of occupancy 0.90 W, 0.10 V), a tetracopper phosphate cation [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)4]4+ (Figure b), and two noncoordinated water molecules, as shown in Figure S5 of the . There are three major discrepancies between the structures of 4 and 5: First, the [PV3W9O40]6− was observed in 4, while [PVW11O40]4− was observed in 5. Second, in 5, two copper atoms in the tetracopper cluster coordinate to one same water, while in 4 each copper atom in the tetracopper cluster coordinates with one water (Figure ). Third, the Cu−Cu distance of the tetracopper parallelogram cluster in complex 5 (3.834(5), 3.388(4) Å) is shorter than those in complex 4 (4.384(3), 3.328(2) Å) (see Table S8 in the ). It may be deduced that the different steric effect and soft-rigid degree of the bpy and phen ligands result in different structures of the tetracopper clusters presenting in 4 and 5, and the different tetracopper clusters may act as templates to yield the formations of different POMs in the two complexes ([PV3W9O40]6− in 4 and [PVW11O40]4− in 5). And the angle between the two pyridine rings of bpy units in complex 5 deviates from zero. For phen, such a deformation is not possible. Such a difference in the Cu−Cu distances also observed in the magnetic properties discussed later. The structural features of complexes 4−5 also confirm that the different steric and soft-rigid ligand can result in different assembling process.
elements.clean_text: Complex 5, which was synthesized from the similar treatment of 4 except for phen replaced by bpy, also consists of a Keggin type anion [PVW11O40]4- (W and V are crystallographically disordered, fixed rate of occupancy 0.90 W, 0.10 V), a tetracopper phosphate cation [Cu4(HPO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)4]4+ (Figure b), and two noncoordinated water molecules, as shown in Figure S5 of the . There are three major discrepancies between the structures of 4 and 5: First, the [PV3W9O40]6- was observed in 4, while [PVW11O40]4- was observed in 5. Second, in 5, two copper atoms in the tetracopper cluster coordinate to one same water, while in 4 each copper atom in the tetracopper cluster coordinates with one water (Figure ). Third, the Cu-Cu distance of the tetracopper parallelogram cluster in complex 5 (3.834(5), 3.388(4) Å) is shorter than those in complex 4 (4.384(3), 3.328(2) Å) (see Table S8 in the ). It may be deduced that the different steric effect and soft-rigid degree of the bpy and phen ligands result in different structures of the tetracopper clusters presenting in 4 and 5, and the different tetracopper clusters may act as templates to yield the formations of different POMs in the two complexes ([PV3W9O40]6- in 4 and [PVW11O40]4- in 5). And the angle between the two pyridine rings of bpy units in complex 5 deviates from zero. For phen, such a deformation is not possible. Such a difference in the Cu-Cu distances also observed in the magnetic properties discussed later. The structural features of complexes 4-5 also confirm that the different steric and soft-rigid ligand can result in different assembling process.

elements.content: Complex 1 forms 1D chain-based on Wells-Dawson type POMs and mixed-valence hexacopper clusters with bpy ligand. The feature of complex 2 is that the Wells−Dawson type polyoxoanions as tridentate inorganic ligand covalently bond to three different copper(II) of two different hexacopper phosphate cation to form an infinite 2D framework, and complex 3 consists of discrete clusters, based on dicopper coordination compounds and Keggin POM building blocks via hydrogen bonding, whereas complexes 4−5 feature in a 1D chain constructed from alternating tetracopper phosphate cations and V5+-substituted Keggin type POM anions as bidentate ligand. It is interesting that changing the ligand from bpy to phen has resulted in a different assembling process and constructed the different structural dimensions of complexes 1−2 and the formations of different POM polyoxoanions in 4−5. The structural features of complexes 2−3 show that the initial pH value of the system plays important role in the construction of complexes. The Keggin or Wells−Dawson type POM building blocks can be synthesized in situ by adjusting the initial pH value under the suitable conditions. The differences in the structures of complexes 3−5 are attributable to the different surface charge density or the coordination ability of the surface oxygen atoms of Keggin type polyoxoanions. Because some W6+ are occupied by low valence V5+, the surface charge density of Keggin POMs of complexes 4−5 becomes larger than that of complex 3. The structural differences of complexes 3−5 also show that for the similar polyoxoanions (such as Keggin), the greater the charge density on the surface oxygen atoms of POMs, the more metal-organic compound units coordinated to the POMs, in agreement with the results reported in literature.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of the Ligand, pH Value, and Lower-Valence Metal on the Structures of Complexes 1-5 

Complex 1 forms 1D chain-based on Wells-Dawson type POMs and mixed-valence hexacopper clusters with bpy ligand. The feature of complex 2 is that the Wells-Dawson type polyoxoanions as tridentate inorganic ligand covalently bond to three different copper(II) of two different hexacopper phosphate cation to form an infinite 2D framework, and complex 3 consists of discrete clusters, based on dicopper coordination compounds and Keggin POM building blocks via hydrogen bonding, whereas complexes 4-5 feature in a 1D chain constructed from alternating tetracopper phosphate cations and V5+-substituted Keggin type POM anions as bidentate ligand. It is interesting that changing the ligand from bpy to phen has resulted in a different assembling process and constructed the different structural dimensions of complexes 1-2 and the formations of different POM polyoxoanions in 4-5. The structural features of complexes 2-3 show that the initial pH value of the system plays important role in the construction of complexes. The Keggin or Wells-Dawson type POM building blocks can be synthesized in situ by adjusting the initial pH value under the suitable conditions. The differences in the structures of complexes 3-5 are attributable to the different surface charge density or the coordination ability of the surface oxygen atoms of Keggin type polyoxoanions. Because some W6+ are occupied by low valence V5+, the surface charge density of Keggin POMs of complexes 4-5 becomes larger than that of complex 3. The structural differences of complexes 3-5 also show that for the similar polyoxoanions (such as Keggin), the greater the charge density on the surface oxygen atoms of POMs, the more metal-organic compound units coordinated to the POMs, in agreement with the results reported in literature.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of complexes 2−5 were recorded between 400 and 4000 cm−1 with KBr pellet (see Figure S6 in the ). The infrared spectrum of 2 exhibits four characteristic asymmetric vibrations for the Wells-Dawson structure, namely, P−Oa 1092 cm−1, W−Ot 959 cm−1, corner-sharing W−Oc−W 900 cm−1, edge-sharing W−Oe−W 794 cm−1, respectively. For the saturated Keggin POMs of complex 3, the P−O stretch exhibits only one peak at 1080 cm−1, different from the infrared spectra of V5+−substituted Keggin of complexes 4−5, which split into three or four bands. The results further confirms that the Keggin anions of complexes 4−5 are not the saturated [PW12O40]3− anion, but the superposition of disordered disubstituted anions. Strong bands at 957−980 cm−1 are assigned to the M = O t (M = W for 3, M = W and V for 4−5) stretching vibrations, peaks between 700 and 900 cm−1 are attributed to M−O b −M stretching modes, and peaks between 550 and 700 cm−1 represent the M−O c −M vibrations. And all the 1150−1700 cm−1 regions are indicative of the organic ligands.

The infrared spectrum of 2 exhibits four characteristic asymmetric vibrations for the Wells-Dawson structure, namely, P-Oa 1092 cm-1, W-Ot 959 cm-1, corner-sharing W-Oc-W 900 cm-1, edge-sharing W-Oe-W 794 cm-1, respectively. For the saturated Keggin POMs of complex 3, the P-O stretch exhibits only one peak at 1080 cm-1, different from the infrared spectra of V5+-substituted Keggin of complexes 4-5, which split into three or four bands. The results further confirms that the Keggin anions of complexes 4-5 are not the saturated [PW12O40]3- anion, but the superposition of disordered disubstituted anions. Strong bands at 957-980 cm-1 are assigned to the M = O t  (M = W for 3, M = W and V for 4-5) stretching vibrations, peaks between 700 and 900 cm-1 are attributed to M-O b -M stretching modes, and peaks between 550 and 700 cm-1 represent the M-O c -M vibrations. And all the 1150-1700 cm-1 regions are indicative of the organic ligands.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of compounds 2−5 were investigated under N2 atmosphere from 40 to 1000 °C, and the TG curves are provided in Figure S7. For complex 2, TG shows a two-step weight loss: the first weight loss of 1.69% (calcd 1.76%) from 40 to 230 °C may be assigned to the removal of H2O, and the second weight loss of 32.28% (calcd 31.80%) at 230−950 °C may be ascribed to decomposition of phen ligands and POMs. The TG curves of anhydrous complex 3 exhibits one step weight loss of 31.21% (calcd 29.08%) below 940 °C ascribed to the decomposition of organic ligands and POMs. The TG curves of 4 and 5 all undergo two step weight loss: the first weight losses of 2.98% for 4 (calcd 2.93%) and 1.93% for 5 (calcd 1.85%) below 270 °C were assigned to the removal of H2O, and the second continuous weight losses of 36.81% for 4 (calcd 36.49%) and 30.94% for 5 (calcd 31.81%) at ca. 270−950 °C may be ascribed to the decomposition of organic ligands and POMs, respectively.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility property of 2 was investigated in the temperature range 2−300 K. The value of χm slowly increases from 8.28 × 10−3 cm3 mol−1 at 300 K to 3.97 × 10−2 cm3 mol−1 at 23 K, then exponentially to the maximum of 0.43 cm3 mol−1 at 2 K (Figure ). The χm T curve displays a continuous decrease upon cooling from 2.48 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K, which is slightly higher than the calculated χm T value of 2.25 cm3 mol−1 K for six uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S = 1/2), to 0.85 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K, indicating significant antiferromagnetic exchange interactions within the hexacopper cores. In addition, the plot of χm −1 versus T in the range of 20−300 K obeys Curie−Weiss equation with the Curie constant C = 2.97 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.19) and Weiss constant θ = −61.00 K, which further confirms the existence of strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu2+ centers. Such a strong antiferromagnetic coupling has been observed in other multicopper clusters.

Magnetic Property of 2 

The magnetic susceptibility property of 2 was investigated in the temperature range 2-300 K. The value of χm slowly increases from 8.28 × 10-3 cm3 mol-1 at 300 K to 3.97 × 10-2 cm3 mol-1 at 23 K, then exponentially to the maximum of 0.43 cm3 mol-1 at 2 K (Figure ). The χm T curve displays a continuous decrease upon cooling from 2.48 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K, which is slightly higher than the calculated χm T value of 2.25 cm3 mol-1 K for six uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S = 1/2), to 0.85 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K, indicating significant antiferromagnetic exchange interactions within the hexacopper cores. In addition, the plot of χm -1 versus T in the range of 20-300 K obeys Curie-Weiss equation with the Curie constant C = 2.97 cm3 mol-1 K (g = 2.19) and Weiss constant θ = -61.00 K, which further confirms the existence of strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu2+ centers. Such a strong antiferromagnetic coupling has been observed in other multicopper clusters.

elements.content: Although there are two different hexacopper phosphate cation judged by the Cu−Cu lengths and Cu−Cu−Cu angles (see Table S9 in the ), their coupling mechanism is very similar when omitting the peripheral ligands (Figure a). Therefore, the first hexacopper phosphate is selected and described in detail to simulate the coupling interaction. In the hexacopper clusters, the Cu−O−Cu coupling is much stronger than the Cu−O−P−O−Cu couplings, so this model can be simplified as one tetracopper and two monocoppers (Figure b). elements.content: The magnetic molar susceptibility (χm) and its temperature product (χm T) versus T plots for complex 3 in the temperature range 2−300 K are shown in Figure S11. The χm T curve displays a continuous decrease upon cooling from 300 to 2 K. The χm T value at room temperature (χm T = 0.75 cm3 mol−1 K) compares very well with the calculated χm T value of 0.75 cm3 mol−1 K for two uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S=1/2). As for the plots of χm −1 versus T, it obeys Curie−Weiss equation with C = 0.82 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.05) and θ = −23.10 K between 50−300 K. Such behaviors of χm T and χm −1 of complex 3 versus T are indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions in the dicopper.

Magnetic Property of 3 

The magnetic molar susceptibility (χm) and its temperature product (χm T) versus T plots for complex 3 in the temperature range 2-300 K are shown in Figure S11. The χm T curve displays a continuous decrease upon cooling from 300 to 2 K. The χm T value at room temperature (χm T = 0.75 cm3 mol-1 K) compares very well with the calculated χm T value of 0.75 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S=1/2). elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility properties of complexes 4−5 were also investigated between 2 and 300 K. The χm T values of complexes 4−5 decrease from 1.60 and 1.69 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K, which compare with the calculated χm T value of 1.67 cm3 mol−1 K for four uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S = 1/2), to 0.14 and 0.72 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K (Figure S12), respectively. As for the plots of χm −1 versus T, it obeys Curie−Weiss equation with the C = 1.69 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.11) and θ = −17.80 K between 20 and 300 K for complex 4, while for complex 5 it also obeys the Curie−Weiss equation with the C = 1.85 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.19) and θ = −26.34 K in the temperature range 30−300 K. Such behavior of χm T and χm −1 of complexes 4−5 versus T is indicative of antiferromagnetically coupled complexes. The susceptibility data were also fitted to the eq for exchange-coupled pairs of copper ions, where J 1, J 2 is the magnetic exchange parameter in the spin Hamiltonian H = −2J 1(S Cu1 S Cu2+S Cu1A S Cu2A) − 2J 2(S Cu1 S Cu2A + S Cu1A S Cu2).

elements.content: The J 1, J 2 values reflect the degree of interaction between the four unpaired electrons in Cu2+ ions through the bridging PO4 tetrahedron and are therefore related to the structure of the complex. The −J 1, −J 2 values (9.36 cm−1, 9.72 cm−1) of complex 5 are larger than those of 4 (6.48 cm−1, 7.41 cm−1). This can be explained by taking into account the difference in the coordination geometry of 4−5. Complex 4 has an unpaired electron mainly in the d z 2 orbital of Cu(1) ion with an elongated octahedral structure, whereas complex 5 has an unpaired electron mainly in the d x 2 −y 2 orbital of each Cu2+ ion with a distorted square-pyramidal structure. The overlap integral between PO4 orbital and Cu2+ d z 2 orbital of complex 4 is expected to have a smaller value than that of complex 5. Maybe the introduction of different steric ligand changes the coordination geometry of Cu2+, and further modulates magnetic properties of complexes 4−5.

elements.content: In summary, a series of organic−inorganic hybrid complexes based on multinuclear copper clusters and POM building blocks have been synthesized in situ and characterized. The Keggin or Wells−Dawson type POM building blocks can be synthesized in situ by adjusting the initial pH value of the system under the suitable conditions. Copper(II), as secondary transition metal, has a key role in the formation of the POM-based hybrid materials because of its capacity to adopt various coordination number and the Jahn−Teller effect allowing an elongation of the axial Cu−O distances. Moreover, different organic ligands used in the synthetic reactions may induce different multicopper clusters which further influence the assembling process and the structures of the final products. To the best of our knowledge, complex 1 represents the first example of a 1D linear chain constructed from alternating mixed-valence hexacopper clusters and Wells-Dawson polyoxoanions. Complex 2 exhibits an unprecedented 2D layer structure containing Wells-Dawson type polyoxometalates linked by two different hexacopper phosphate cations. The structural differences of complexes 3−5 show that for the similar polyoxoanions (such as Keggin) the greater the charge density on the surface oxygen atoms of POMs, the more metal-organic compound units coordinated to the POMs. Magnetic studies of complexes 2−5 show that antiferromagnetic interactions dominate between the Cu2+ centers. The work may provide helpful information for the design and construction of POM-based hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a series of organic-inorganic hybrid complexes based on multinuclear copper clusters and POM building blocks have been synthesized in situ and characterized. The Keggin or Wells-Dawson type POM building blocks can be synthesized in situ by adjusting the initial pH value of the system under the suitable conditions. Copper(II), as secondary transition metal, has a key role in the formation of the POM-based hybrid materials because of its capacity to adopt various coordination number and the Jahn-Teller effect allowing an elongation of the axial Cu-O distances. Moreover, different organic ligands used in the synthetic reactions may induce different multicopper clusters which further influence the assembling process and the structures of the final products. To the best of our knowledge, complex 1 represents the first example of a 1D linear chain constructed from alternating mixed-valence hexacopper clusters and Wells-Dawson polyoxoanions. Complex 2 exhibits an unprecedented 2D layer structure containing Wells-Dawson type polyoxometalates linked by two different hexacopper phosphate cations. The structural differences of complexes 3-5 show that for the similar polyoxoanions (such as Keggin) the greater the charge density on the surface oxygen atoms of POMs, the more metal-organic compound units coordinated to the POMs. Magnetic studies of complexes 2-5 show that antiferromagnetic interactions dominate between the Cu2+ centers. The work may provide helpful information for the design and construction of POM-based hybrid materials.

A mixture of Na2WO4·2H2O (0.383 g, 1.16 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.032 g, 0.19 mmol), H3PO4 (0.5 mL, 85%), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.023 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (18 mL) was stirred for 30 min, and the pH was adjusted to 2.5−3 with 2 M NaOH solution. The resulting suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (25 mL) and kept at 160 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature for 2 days, blue prism crystals of 1 were obtained by filtering and were washed with distilled water and dried in desiccators at ambient temperature. The yield was ca. 42% based on W. Elemental anal. Calcd (%) for C72H60Cu6N12O76P4W18 (2) (M r = 6123.74) (%): W, 54.04; Cu, 6.23; P, 2.02; C, 14.12; H, 0.99; N, 2.75. Found (%): W, 53.69; Cu, 6.19; P, 2.27; C, 14.32; H, 1.06; N, 2.83.

Complex 3 was prepared similar to 2, except that the pH was between 0.5 and 1, without the addition of 2 M NaOH solution. Light green needle crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained in a 45% yield based on Cu. Anal. Synthesis of [Cu6(PO4)2(H2O)4(phen)6](H2O)2[P2W18O62] (2)

A mixture of Na2WO4⋅2H2O (0.383 g, 1.16 mmol), CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.032 g, 0.19 mmol), H3PO4 (0.5 mL, 85%), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.023 g, 0.12 mmol), and H2O (18 mL) was stirred for 30 min, and the pH was adjusted to 2.5-3 with 2 M NaOH solution. The resulting suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (25 mL) and kept at 160 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature for 2 days, blue prism crystals of 1 were obtained by filtering and were washed with distilled water and dried in desiccators at ambient temperature. The yield was ca. 42% based on W. Elemental anal. Calcd (%) for C72H60Cu6N12O76P4W18 (2) (M r = 6123.74) (%): W, 54.04; Cu, 6.23; P, 2.02; C, 14.12; H, 0.99; N, 2.75. Found (%): W, 53.69; Cu, 6.19; P, 2.27; C, 14.32; H, 1.06; N, 2.83.

Synthesis of [Cu2Cl(phen)4][PW12O40] (3)

Complex 3 was prepared similar to 2, except that the pH was between 0.5 and 1, without the addition of 2 M NaOH solution. Light green needle crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained in a 45% yield based on Cu. Anal. cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities of compounds 2−5 were investigated under N2 atmosphere from 40 to 1000 °C, and the TG curves are provided in Figure S7. For complex 2, TG shows a two-step weight loss: the first weight loss of 1.69% (calcd 1.76%) from 40 to 230 °C may be assigned to the removal of H2O, and the second weight loss of 32.28% (calcd 31.80%) at 230−950 °C may be ascribed to decomposition of phen ligands and POMs. The TG curves of anhydrous complex 3 exhibits one step weight loss of 31.21% (calcd 29.08%) below 940 °C ascribed to the decomposition of organic ligands and POMs. The TG curves of 4 and 5 all undergo two step weight loss: the first weight losses of 2.98% for 4 (calcd 2.93%) and 1.93% for 5 (calcd 1.85%) below 270 °C were assigned to the removal of H2O, and the second continuous weight losses of 36.81% for 4 (calcd 36.49%) and 30.94% for 5 (calcd 31.81%) at ca. 270−950 °C may be ascribed to the decomposition of organic ligands and POMs, respectively.

Magnetic Property of <bold>2</bold>

The magnetic susceptibility property of 2 was investigated in the temperature range 2−300 K. The value of χm slowly increases from 8.28 × 10−3 cm3 mol−1 at 300 K to 3.97 × 10−2 cm3 mol−1 at 23 K, then exponentially to the maximum of 0.43 cm3 mol−1 at 2 K (Figure ). The χm T curve displays a continuous decrease upon cooling from 2.48 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K, which is slightly higher than the calculated χm T value of 2.25 cm3 mol−1 K for six uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S = 1/2), to 0.85 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K, indicating significant antiferromagnetic exchange interactions within the hexacopper cores. In addition, the plot of χm −1 versus T in the range of 20−300 K obeys Curie−Weiss equation with the Curie constant C = 2.97 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.19) and Weiss constant θ = −61.00 K, which further confirms the existence of strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu2+ centers. Such a strong antiferromagnetic coupling has been observed in other multicopper clusters.

Magnetic Property of <bold>3</bold>

The magnetic molar susceptibility (χm) and its temperature product (χm T) versus T plots for complex 3 in the temperature range 2−300 K are shown in Figure S11. The χm T curve displays a continuous decrease upon cooling from 300 to 2 K. The χm T value at room temperature (χm T = 0.75 cm3 mol−1 K) compares very well with the calculated χm T value of 0.75 cm3 mol−1 K for two uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S=1/2). As for the plots of χm −1 versus T, it obeys Curie−Weiss equation with C = 0.82 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.05) and θ = −23.10 K between 50−300 K. Such behaviors of χm T and χm −1 of complex 3 versus T are indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions in the dicopper.

Magnetic Properties of <bold>4</bold>−<bold>5</bold>

The magnetic susceptibility properties of complexes 4−5 were also investigated between 2 and 300 K. The χm T values of complexes 4−5 decrease from 1.60 and 1.69 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K, which compare with the calculated χm T value of 1.67 cm3 mol−1 K for four uncoupled spins Cu2+ (S = 1/2), to 0.14 and 0.72 cm3 mol−1 K at 2 K (Figure S12), respectively. As for the plots of χm −1 versus T, it obeys Curie−Weiss equation with the C = 1.69 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.11) and θ = −17.80 K between 20 and 300 K for complex 4, while for complex 5 it also obeys the Curie−Weiss equation with the C = 1.85 cm3 mol−1 K (g = 2.19) and θ = −26.34 K in the temperature range 30−300 K. Such behavior of χm T and χm −1 of complexes 4−5 versus T is indicative of antiferromagnetically coupled complexes. The susceptibility data were also fitted to the eq for exchange-coupled pairs of copper ions, where J 1, J 2 is the magnetic exchange parameter in the spin Hamiltonian H = −2J 1(S Cu1 S Cu2+S Cu1A S Cu2A) − 2J 2(S Cu1 S Cu2A + S Cu1A S Cu2).

metadata.title: Hydrothermal Syntheses, Crystal Structures, And Magnetic Properties of a Series of Complexes Constructed from Multinuclear Copper Clusters and Polyoxometalates
